title: Empirical Bayes Methods
description: Understanding empirical Bayes methods for estimating hyperparameters from data in hierarchical models.
learning_objectives: Apply empirical Bayes in Active Inference
Compare empirical vs full Bayesian methods

content.overview: Empirical Bayes methods estimate hyperparameters from the data itself, rather than specifying them as fixed prior beliefs. This approach combines the benefits of hierarchical modeling with data-driven parameter estimation.

methodological_approach.evidence_maximization: Maximize marginal likelihood: φ* = argmax_φ p(x|φ)
methodological_approach.two_step_procedure: 1. Estimate φ from data, 2. Use φ to compute posterior p(θ|x, φ*)

types_of_empirical_bayes.description: Assume parametric form for hyperparameter distribution
types_of_empirical_bayes.method: Maximize marginal likelihood analytically or numerically
Use kernel density estimation or other smoothing methods
types_of_empirical_bayes.example: Estimate prior distribution from empirical distribution

examples.name: Beta-Binomial Model
examples.description: Estimate Beta parameters from binomial data
examples.data: Success counts from multiple binomial experiments
examples.estimation: α*, β* = argmax p(x|α, β) = ∏_i Beta-binomial(x_i|α, β)
examples.posterior: p(θ_i|x) = Beta(θ_i|α* + x_i, β* + n_i - x_i)

examples.name: Normal-Normal Model
examples.description: Estimate variance parameters from Gaussian data
examples.estimation: σ* = argmax p(x|σ) across all groups
examples.posterior: θ_j|x ~ N(μ_j*, σ_j*) where σ_j* incorporates estimated σ*

advantages: Often more efficient than full Bayesian methods
disadvantages: Can overfit if data is limited
Not fully Bayesian - doesn't account for hyperparameter uncertainty
May not be appropriate when hyperparameters are of interest

connections_to_active_inference.adaptive_systems: Systems that learn their own priors

computational_methods.analytical_solutions: When marginal likelihood has closed form

interactive_exercises.description: Compare empirical Bayes vs full Bayesian methods

common_misconceptions.misconception: Empirical Bayes is not truly Bayesian
common_misconceptions.clarification: It's Bayesian at the data level but not at hyperparameter level
Depends on amount of data and model complexity
Related but operates in hierarchical framework
